awd_titl_txt: CCF-BSF: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Coding and Information - Theoretic Aspects of Local Data Recovery
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies fundamental problems in data coding that can improve the efficiency of distributed storage systems by increasing data reliability and availability while reducing storage overhead compared to existing industry standards. The results of this research can benefit storage applications ranging from financial, scientific monitoring, and signal processing to social networks and sharing platforms. The new combinatorial, coding, and information theoretic tools developed in this project will be incorporated in course curricula in the respective institutions of the principal investigators.

Data coding with locality, the focus of this project, is a rapidly developing area of coding theory that was initially motivated by applications in distributed storage, and has links to many areas of network science (e.g., index coding and network coding) as well as to computer science. This project advances the theory and practice of data coding with local recovery by investigating broad implications of the locality constraint in coding problems. These include studying new error-correcting code families and their decoding, fundamental limitations on the code parameters and capacity bounds under the requirements of local data recovery. The newly designed coding schemes developed in this project will be validated through implementation and evaluation in simulated computer environment, aiming at enhanced performance of data coding in current industry solutions.

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to a range of problems in coding and information theory motivated by emerging applications in distributed systems. This project furthered research to show that functionality of distributed computing and storage-systems can be improved by introducing coding-theoretic solutions that are suitable for 1) fast and efficient recovery of data in the case of malfunction of one or more servers, 2) making large distributed systems communication efficient, and 3) making distributed optimization processes robust.
Through this project several fundamental scientific results were obtained. Firstly, the best known trade-off of storage-overhead and error-resilience for locally repairable codes, a fimily of error-correcting codes for distributed storage, were obtained under different failure models. Secondly, solutions to the problem of node failures in distributed  systems were provided by means of error-correcting codes. And lastly, communication-efficient schemes for large distributed systems running machine learning algorithms were provided. Two graduate students at University of Massachusetts has been supported by this grant in parts for the past three years. The elements of this project has been incorporated into newly designed/redesigned courses of information theory, coding theory, optimization, and data science at University of Massachusetts. 

 
Several invited and contributed talks on the results of this project has been delivered by the PI and students in universities, research labs and in conferences. The project also led to collaborations with other faculty members and postdoctoral researchers. The collaborative project also led to organization of special sessions on dedicated topics within international conferences.
The results of this project is disseminated via at least four (4) journal papers and eight (8) highly selective conference papers.
